subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.
If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg.
Too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

meta_summary.title: $meta$
meta_summary.goal: To make a dish that resembles Pasta Carbonara but is explicitly not traditional Carbonara.
goal_quotes: Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
meta_summary.objects: Bacon, egg yolks, pecorino romano cheese, spaghetti, pasta water, pepper.
objects_quotes: The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan.
meta_summary.outcome: A pasta dish that resembles Carbonara in appearance and taste but is intentionally not traditional Carbonara, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and other non-traditional methods.
outcome_quotes: And here we don't have carbonara.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
meta_summary.instructions: 1. Chop bacon into small pieces. 2. Separate egg yolks from whites and set aside the yolks. 3. Grate pecorino romano cheese and mix it with the egg yolks. 4. Add pepper to the egg and cheese mixture. 5. Cook spaghetti in salted boiling water. 6. Cook bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly. 7. Add a bit of pasta water to the egg and cheese mixture. 8. Transfer cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the bacon pan. 9. Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring to combine. 10. Add more pasta water if needed to achieve a creamy consistency. 11. Finish with additional pepper and grated cheese before serving.
instructions_quotes: The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Now our bacon is cooked. We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.
Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan.
meta_summary.rationale: The steps are designed to create a creamy pasta dish that resembles carbonara. Bacon is used instead of guanciale for flavor. Egg yolks and cheese create a rich sauce that is thickened by the heat of the pasta. Pasta water is added to help emulsify the sauce and achieve the desired creamy texture.
rationale_quotes: That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
meta_summary.tips: 1. Use guanciale instead of bacon for authentic carbonara. 2. Be careful not to overcook the egg-based sauce by letting the pan cool slightly before adding the egg mixture. 3. Reserve pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency. 4. Avoid breaking spaghetti to maintain its texture. 5. Finish with extra cheese and pepper for added flavor.
tips_quotes: If you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
If you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water.

metadata.title: Not Spaghetti Carbonara - You Suck at Cooking (episode 138)

subtitles.text: You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.
It's so simple!
Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.
Let's not waste any time, now let's go!
Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.
So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon.
And thickcut bacon would be best.
You could also use pancetta.
So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.
That's about three quarters of an inch.
Turn this pan on to medium heat.
I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right.
Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan, and what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy.
We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?
Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water.
Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.
So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese.
Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged.
I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano.
That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff.

meta_summary.instructions:
1. Slice thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
2. Heat a pan on medium and add a tiny bit of olive oil.
3. Add bacon to the pan and render the fat until crispy.
4. Boil water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
5. Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely.
6. Mix three whole eggs and two egg yolks in a bowl.
7. Whisk grated cheese into the egg mixture.
8. Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture.
9. Add a quarter cup of boiling pasta water to the egg mixture to temper it.
10. Cook spaghetti until slightly al dente.
11. Turn off the heat and drain most of the bacon fat, leaving about two tablespoons.
12. Add cooked spaghetti to the pan with bacon fat.
13. Add egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs.
14. If needed, use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency.
15. Plate the pasta and garnish with more cheese and crispy bacon.
instructions_quotes: "Slice this just pretty thick, this way. That's about three quarters of an inch."
"Turn this pan on to medium heat."
"Break your bacon into that pan, and what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy."
"Season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water."
"Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely."
"I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks."
"Whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture."
"Put quite a bit of Gilbert's insides into this egg mixture."
"Take a little bit of that boiling water and add it to the eggs. Quickly whisk that in."
"We'll cook this spaghetti about 10 minutes in this pot, just slightly al dente."
"Turn off the heat of this pan, and I'm going to drain off most of the fat, all except for about two tablespoons or so."
"Drop that in there. Trust me, this spaghetti is generating a ridiculous amount of heat."
"Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture."
"If it looks too thick to you, also what you can do is just add a little bit of that pasta water."
"Just get it off the tongs like so. Oh, man. Now to finish a little more pan migliano reggiano."
meta_summary.rationale: The steps are designed to create a creamy carbonara sauce without scrambling the eggs. Using bacon instead of guanciale makes the recipe more accessible. The combination of cheeses adds depth of flavor. Tempering the egg mixture with hot pasta water prevents the eggs from scrambling when mixed with the hot pasta. The rendered bacon fat adds flavor and helps emulsify the sauce.
rationale_quotes: "Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale... but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon."
"Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water."
"Carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks."
"We're kind of equalizing the temperatures here and loosening up this egg mixture a little bit, and it's going to make the whole pasta come together a lot easier in the end."
"The whole trick here, and what you really need to keep in mind is that we do not want to scramble these eggs."
meta_summary.tips:
- Use thick-cut bacon or pancetta for best results.
- Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano are preferred cheeses.
- Avoid adding olive oil to the pasta water; it's unnecessary.
- Use pasta water to adjust sauce consistency if needed.
- Be gentle when mixing the egg mixture with the pasta to avoid scrambling.
- If the sauce is too thick, add a bit of pasta water to loosen it.
- Use a pan that retains heat well to help cook the egg mixture gently.
tips_quotes: "Thickcut bacon would be best. You could also use pancetta."
"Make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff."
"We're going to put some olive oil in this pasta. No, we're not going to do that. Why do people do that? It's a myth."
"If it looks too thick to you, also what you can do is just add a little bit of that pasta water."
"Gentle with the pasta. You don't want to break it."
"If it doesn't thicken up like you like, literally what you can do is set that pan back on top of that pasta water and like a double boil or bainmarie, it will keep cooking the egg mixture."
